content.en:
ยซMarburg: The Unexpected Epidemic โ All the Details You Need to Know Nowยป

This post is long and compiles information about the Marburg virus (MVD). This is for awareness, but official and trusted information remains with medical specialists and the Ministry of Health. You will understand what the disease is, how it appeared, how it is transmitted, its symptoms in detail from day one to the critical stage, a practical comparison with COVID-19, and the current situation in Egypt and neighboring Arab countries.

History of Appearance and Known Outbreaks

Marburg virus was first recognized in 1967 when laboratory workers in Germany were infected by lab monkeys. Since then, the disease has appeared intermittently in several African countries: Uganda, Kenya, Congo, Rwanda, and Tanzania. Outbreaks are usually localized and limited, but mortality rates can be very high.

Recently, we have seen a wave of outbreaks in East AfricaโRwanda in 2024, Tanzania in early 2025, and most recently Ethiopia in November 2025, where health authorities confirmed cases and deaths. Each outbreak varies in case numbers and fatality rates depending on the speed of response and the capacity of the health system.

Animal Source and Spillover to Humans

The known natural reservoir for the virus is the Egyptian Rousette bat. These bats can carry the virus without symptoms. When humans enter bat habitats (like caves or mines) or eat undercooked meat from untrusted sources, the virus can "spillover" to humans. Afterward, if human-to-human transmission occurs, the infection spreads primarily through contact with infected body fluids.

How is the Virus Transmitted?

Infection occurs through direct contact with the body fluids of an infected personโblood, saliva, vomit, urine, fecesโor by touching surfaces contaminated with the virus (fomites). Additionally, the bodies of those who died from the disease can be a source of infection if burials are handled without precautions. Important point: Marburg is NOT airborne; it is not like influenza or COVID-19 in terms of aerial transmission. A person is usually not contagious before symptoms appear.

Current Situation in Egypt and Neighboring Countries

In Egypt, the Ministry of Health and Population has officially confirmed that no Marburg cases have been recorded in the country. The health system is operating on strong epidemiological surveillance at airports, seaports, and reference labs for rapid diagnosis.

In neighboring Arab countries, governments are also vigilant: the Saudi Ministry of Health has issued preventive policies and is preparing health centers. Health authorities in Jordan have official protocols for contact tracing. In Libya, the National Center for Disease Control has alerted the public via official media to remain vigilant, especially travelers from countries with reported cases.

Summary: To date, there is no confirmation of any outbreak in Egypt or major Arab countries. Official policies focus on readiness, early reporting, and contact tracing along with public awareness of hygiene measures.

Incubation Period and Detailed Symptoms

The period between exposure and onset of symptoms ranges from 2 to 21 days, with an average of 5 to 10 days.

  • Phase 1 โ Acute Onset (Days 1โ3): Sudden high fever, severe headache, myalgia, and general fatigue.
  • Phase 2 โ Gastrointestinal (Days 3โ7): Nausea, vomiting, severe watery diarrhea (starting day 3), and abdominal pain.
  • Phase 3 โ Bleeding & Complications (Days 5โ10+): Bleeding from nose/gums, bruising/petechiae under the skin, internal bleeding, and multi-organ failure in severe cases.

Diagnosis and Treatment

Diagnosis requires PCR testing. Currently, there is no approved antiviral treatment or vaccine for general use. Treatment depends on supportive care: oral/IV rehydration, oxygen therapy, and managing blood pressure and coagulation disorders.

Marburg vs. COVID-19

  • Transmission: COVID-19 is airborne/droplet-based; Marburg requires direct contact with body fluids.
  • Fatality Rate: COVID-19 is low (<1%), whereas Marburg mortality rates can reach up to 88% in some outbreaks.

Debunking Common Myths

  • Marburg is not airborne like COVID-19.
  • Supportive care significantly improves survival chances even without a specific vaccine.

Medical Note: This article is for general information; it is best to consult medical specialists and the Ministry of Health.

title.en: The Intelligence That Could Defeat Us? A Journey from the Beginnings to Superintelligence

summary.en: A comprehensive review of AI evolution from narrow systems to general and superintelligence, explaining driving technologies, expert opinions, technical and ethical challenges, and practical recommendations for organizations to ensure safety and alignment with human values.

content.en:
The Intelligence That Could Defeat Us? A Journey from the Beginnings to Superintelligence

Artificial Intelligenceโnot just in general terms. We will look at the differences between types: Weak AI, Strong AI (Artificial General Intelligence - AGI), and what everyone feels cautious or excited about: Superintelligence.

The Start of the Story - History and Evolution in Stages

The idea that machines can "think" is not new at all. From Alan Turing's ideas in the mid-20th century, around 1958, to naming in conferences in the fifties, the journey had its ups and downs. There were periods of "AI uncertainty" because expectations were higher than capabilities, and other periods of progress due to data availability and stronger computing powers. The real transformation happened with the emergence of:

  • Machine Learning: A branch that teaches the machine from data instead of programming everything literally.
  • Deep Learning: A type of machine learning that relies on artificial neural networks (Neural Networks), which learn complex representations of data and can produce powerful results in vision and language processing.

These developments led to large models capable of generating text, images, and audio with acceptable quality, allowing many applications to hit the market quickly.

Definition of Types โ Detailed and Simplified Explanation

  • Narrow AI / Weak AI: These are systems highly specialized in a specific task: diagnosing medical images, recommending products, or operating a voice assistant. They are smart, but in only one field, and they lack a general understanding of the world.
  • Artificial General Intelligence (AGI): This is a system that can learn and solve any mental task like a human without specific training for each task. It can learn languages, solve physics problems, write research, and make inferences in new fields. This is still in research and discussion, but many are trying to crack this code.
  • Superintelligence: If AGI develops further and surpasses us in all fieldsโspeed, accuracy, depthโhere we talk about Superintelligence. An entity that could innovate solutions we might not easily comprehend and change the rules of the game entirely.

Technology and How Models Work โ Simplified

  • Neural Networks: Interconnected layers that transform data into internal representations, with each layer learning deeper features.
  • GPT (Generative Pre-trained Transformer) and Transformers: A method where we train a large model on a massive amount of text and then use it in diverse applicationsโwriting, translation, generation.
  • Foundation Models: Massive models trained on diverse data to provide a "knowledge base" used in multiple applications.
  • Reinforcement Learning: Teaches the agent through trial and error, like learning a game after repeated attempts.
  • Explainable AI: Tools that attempt to explain why the model decided something, which is vital for trust and safety.

Practical Applications

Narrow AI is all around us. Here are detailed examples to clarify the picture:

  1. Healthcare: Systems help in diagnosis from X-rays, facilitating the rapid detection of tumors or anomalies. In some cases, these models improved diagnosis accuracy and reduced waiting times, but they always function as "supporting tools," not replacements for the doctor's decision. Research also uses AI to accelerate drug discovery and effective simulation trials.
  2. Finance & Economics: Algorithms analyze thousands of transactions in a second, detecting fraud and helping banks manage risks. However, if the model is trained on biased data, the decision could marginalize certain groupsโa real challenge occurring on the ground.
  3. Industry & Robotics: Robots in factories perform assembly, welding, and product inspection with higher precision and repetition than humans in routine tasks. Combined with the Internet of Things (IoT), we can monitor equipment and prevent failures before they occur.
  4. Education: Smart platforms provide adaptive content according to the student's level, conduct instant tests, and suggest personalized learning paths, making education more effective and flexible.
  5. Media & Entertainment: Text, image, and video generators have reduced content production costs. This is good for small creators but also raises issues of intellectual property and transparencyโwho owns the generated content? And how do we distinguish between the real and the fabricated?
  6. Security & Defense: AI helps detect cyber threats and analyze intelligence imagery, but the same progress could be used to develop smart weapons or falsify information, showing that every technology has two sides.

Expert Opinions โ Important and Influential Differences

Opinions vary, and some are bold in their estimates:

  • Mustafa Suleyman (Microsoft): Stated that seeking to build a "Superintelligence" that exceeds humans is not a goal companies should adopt, describing this pursuit as an "anti-goal" we must avoidโa warning against loss of control and the difficulty of aligning such goals with human values.
  • Sam Altman (OpenAI): Believes that achieving AGI is important and that what follows AGI could be Superintelligence. His view is that responsible development can offer significant scientific and economic opportunities if handled correctly.
  • Demis Hassabis (DeepMind): Estimated that AGI could happen within five to ten years in the safest estimates, making the discussion of safety and policy a priority now.

Deep Technical Problems โ Why is it so difficult?

  • Alignment Problem: How do we make the machine's goals compatible with human values? Any simple goal could achieve unintended results if the machine chooses a "shortcut" to achieve it.
  • Interpretability: Large models are sometimes a "black box"โwe see inputs and outputs but don't understand the reason for the decision. This reduces trust in critical systems.
  • Robustness and Reliability: Systems can degrade or be deceived by minor changes in data (adversarial attacks).
  • Data Bias: If data is biased, the model will perpetuate that biasโa clear social danger.

Tools and Techniques for AI "Alignment"

Researchers are trying practical ways to reduce risk and increase safety:

  1. Multi-level Goal Design: Dividing the general goal into small, reviewable goals.
  2. Human Preference Learning: Training models on human choices to learn their values instead of rigid numerical goals.
  3. Sandbox Testing: Testing in simulations before launching the system to the world.
  4. Audit Trails and Red Teams: Teams that try to hack or deceive the model to reveal vulnerabilities and record every action for later examination.
  5. Explainable AI tools: Developing methods to make model decisions understandable by humans.
  6. Capability Control: Restricting the model's powers and preventing it from accessing full implementation means without supervision.

Practical Case Studies

  • Medical Case: A hospital used a diagnostic system as an assistant. Results: Higher accuracy and faster diagnosis, but when they relied on the system without international review, errors appeared. Lesson: Use it as decision support, not a final decision.
  • Financial Case: A bank reduced the percentage of non-performing loans with a smart model, but discovered biases against specific categories. Lesson: Review your data before applying.
  • Media Case: An advertising company used models to generate videos, but issues of ownership and transparency aroseโwe need clear rules for using generated content.

Ethical Frameworks Institutions Can Adopt

  • Transparency: Informing users that they are dealing with an automated system.
  • Responsibility and Accountability: There must be an entity responsible for the system's results.
  • Fairness: Avoiding bias and ensuring benefits reach everyone.
  • Safety: Rigorous testing before deployment.
  • Privacy: Protecting user data and not using it without consent.

Practical Recommendations for Tech Institutions (International)

  1. Before Launch: Conduct social and security impact assessments.
  2. Form ethical safety teams including external experts and civil society representatives.
  3. Share test results with local and international regulatory bodies.
  4. Invest in reskilling programs for affected workers.
  5. Ensure diversity in development teams to reduce biases.

Role of the International Community โ Why does the world need agreements?

This technology does not stop at a country's borders; there must be international coordination: preventing dangerous AI weapons, agreements to exchange information about threats, or laws that protect digital rights globally.

Timeline Indicators and Probabilities โ Will we see AGI soon?

No one can determine a definitive date. Optimists talk about a few years, while conservatives say decades. The important thing is not the exact release date, but that we are prepared securely and legally if a powerful system emerges.

Quick FAQ Guide

  • Does Superintelligence mean evil? Not necessarily; the danger comes from wrong goals or lack of alignment, not from an "evil intent."
  • Can we stop the research? Practically noโthere are massive economic and scientific motives, but we can set controls and policies.
  • How can I ensure product safety if my company develops it? Follow ethical principles, test in controlled environments, and work on interpretability.

Economic and Social Impact โ Details we must understand

  • Labor Market: Jobs disappear and others appear; history teaches us that transformation can create opportunities but the transition is difficult and needs support policies.
  • Digital Divide: Technologically strong countries will gain more, and inequality might increase.
  • Power and Influence: Countries that control advanced technologies will possess global strategic influence.

Potential Future Scenarios โ Roadmaps for Thinking

  • Conservative Scenario: Continued development of Narrow AI and improving quality of life without AGI.
  • Transitional Scenario: Gradual arrival of AGI with critical moments for governance and alignment.
  • Extreme Scenario: Rapid emergence of Superintelligence creating a major turning pointโthis scenario has existential possibilities and requires doubled global preparation.

Final Advice

  • If you work in the field: Be responsible and work on transparency and safety.
  • If you are a government official: Develop flexible policies that support social transition and necessary laws before use.
  • If you are a citizen: Learn the basics and support demands for digital rights protection.

Conclusion

Narrow or Weak AI exists and is changing tangible things in our lives. Reaching AGI or Superintelligence is a scientific possibility with great benefits but real risks if we do not set clear rules. The solution: a balance between innovation and responsibility, investment in safety, and international cooperation to protect our future. International cooperation ensures that this technology serves people rather than replacing them, and remains unbiased or extremist, especially against humans.

title.en: Terrifying Figures... The Egyptian Child on the Scale of Deprivation: Why are 6.6 Million Children Deprived of Basic Life Essentials?

summary.en: An analysis of multi-dimensional poverty figures among Egyptian children, highlighting the deprivation of 6.6 million children from basic needs like health and education, featuring successful global experiences and a roadmap for solutions.

content.en:
Terrifying Figures... The Egyptian Child on the Scale of Deprivation

We are not talking about "poverty" in the narrow sense of just lacking money. We are talking about Multi-Dimensional Poverty (MPI) โ meaning a child is deprived of multiple dimensions of life simultaneously: education, health and nutrition, housing and basic services, and social protection. This is not just a number on a page; it is the future of a child who might not complete their natural growth, education, or health if not addressed quickly and smartly.

Recent figures from Egypt's official agency revealed worrying numbers: approximately 6.6 million children suffer from multi-dimensional poverty, representing about 16.9% of Egypt's children under 18. This means one out of every six children is deprived of two or more basic life essentials. More distressingly, about 1.6 million of them suffer from extreme poverty, meaning deprivation in three or more dimensions. This should be an alarm and a warning to the conscience of both society and the state.

The Current Situation

Looking at the big picture: the number of children in Egypt (0โ17 years) is close to 40 million. Out of this massive number, about 6.6 million are deprived in multiple dimensions, and 1.6 million are severely deprived. Indicators show that younger children, especially those under 5, are the most vulnerable group: MPI rates among them reach about 20.8%, compared to 16.6% for children aged 5-11 and 13.5% for adolescents aged 12-17.

Multi-Dimensional Poverty: How is it Measured?

Traditional measures assess poverty by income only. However, the Multi-Dimensional Poverty Index (MPI) looks at whether a child is simultaneously deprived of essential requirements. These dimensions cover:

  • Education: (attendance/quality).
  • Health and Nutrition: (nutrition, vaccinations).
  • Housing and Basic Services: (water, sanitation, electricity).
  • Social Protection: (social protection, child labour).

Root Causes: Why are Children Suffering?

  1. Economic Pressure: As family income decreases, choices become limited, especially with inflation and the rising cost of living.
  2. Infrastructure Deficit: Lack of clean water or sanitation directly increases diseases and malnutrition.
  3. Weak Social Protection: Financial support might not reach those most in need or isn't linked to educational and health incentives.
  4. Demographic Pressure: A high percentage of children puts immense pressure on schools and hospitals.
  5. Socio-Cultural Factors: Illiteracy and social habits that prevent children, especially girls, from accessing proper education or care.

Global Lessons

  • Tanzania: Achieved significant progress in reducing child poverty by 46 percentage points through cash transfers and service improvements.
  • Bangladesh: Reduced child poverty by 32 percentage points through infrastructure policies and campaigns to eliminate open defecation.

Roadmap for Egypt

  • Focus on the first five years: Early nutrition and growth monitoring programs.
  • Expand water and sanitation services: Urgent investments in villages.
  • Improve education quality: Teacher training and appropriate tools in marginalized areas.
  • Smart Conditional Cash Transfers: Linking support to school attendance and health checkups.
  • Empowering Women: Supporting mothers economically directly benefits children's health and nutrition.

Conclusion

Multi-dimensional child poverty is not just a number: it is a deprivation of things that determine a child's future for a lifetime. Solutions are available and globally proven: a mix of smart cash support, improved water, sanitation, health, and education, and a focus on young children.

title.en: Between Fake Boldnessโฆ and Reality Stranger than Fiction: Films and Series Escaping RealityโWho Are We Fooling?

summary.en: A critique of the current artistic scene, comparing it with masterpieces of political and realistic cinema, highlighting the gap between on-screen depictions and the reality of the Egyptian people, while addressing electoral awareness with a satirical touch.

content.en:
Between Fake Boldnessโฆ and Reality Stranger than Fiction: Films and Series Escaping RealityโWho Are We Fooling?

Since we are in the election season, I recently saw a statement by Amr Youssef who thinks artistic boldness is just saying a slang word like 'Fshkh'. Besides that word, the film contains scenes that are completely unfit for display, not to mention the sexual innuendos. I wonder if he hasn't seen films like 'Birds of Darkness', 'Against the Government', 'Terrorism and Kebab', 'The Yacoubian Building', 'Al-Karnak', 'Revealing the Hidden', 'The Era of Hatem Zahran', 'He Left and Never Returned', 'Love in the Refrigerator', 'Nagi Al-Ali', 'So the Smoke Won't Fly', 'A Touch of Fear', 'Chaos', or other films that even changed laws like 'They Made Me a Criminal', and dark comedies like the famous 'Bittersweet' (Assal Eswed).

Almost all films and series have become detached from reality, to the extent that the President spoke about this a few days ago, stating that the reason for the increase in divorce rates is what appears in films as a fake reality that two-thirds of the people cannot afford to live in (statements in the comments).

This is just one fake point in films and series, but there are certainly more. Returning to the post's topic and the artist, didn't he see a scene like this? If he doesn't have time for a full movie! I was just watching a very expressive video talking to people to raise awareness that their voice matters and they shouldn't sell it. He gave a literal 'bullseye' example: He told them, "Giving your vote in elections for 200 EGP? Even a young donkey costs 2000 EGP!" (Of course, I don't need to tell you what rank that puts you in if you do that ๐).

(Note: that is the lowest market price; prices range from 2000 to 10000, with an average of 6000). As one post I saw said: If you decide to sell your vote to a candidate, don't accept less than 20,000 EGP, because that's the price of a donkey now. Don't be a donkey and a cheap one too. (Note: this is also the lowest market price; prices range from 20,000 to 35,000, with an average of 27,500).

title.en: When the Internet Suddenly Stops โ The Story of the Outage that Hit Cloudflare and Choked Half the World

summary.en: A comprehensive technical analysis of the global outage that hit Cloudflare on November 18, 2025, explaining the causes of the failure in Bot Mitigation systems, its impact on internet infrastructure, and lessons learned for companies and users.

content.en:
When the Internet Suddenly Stops!

Yesterday, people were online and suddenly found many sites not opening or giving error pages. The issue isn't from your router or the site alone โ it's an infrastructure-level crisis, specifically in Cloudflare.

What is Cloudflare?

Cloudflare is a global web infrastructure company acting as a "gateway" between users and the original server. Its main job is to provide speed, security, and reduce server load. Key services include:

  • Content Delivery Network (CDN): Storing content copies on distributed servers globally for speed.
  • DDoS Protection: Defending against attacks that flood sites with fake traffic.
  • DNS: Providing fast and secure DNS like the 1.1.1.1 service.
  • Web Application Firewall (WAF): Filtering requests to prevent hacks like SQL Injection.
  • Edge Services: Such as Workers, Access, and WARP.

Why is Cloudflare so critical?

Cloudflare has a highly distributed network and data centers in many locations, handling massive traffic. This has led global companies, governments, and major platforms to rely on it. This high dependency means any issue doesn't just affect one site, but thousands simultaneously โ which is exactly what happened.

When and how did it happen?

On Tuesday, November 18, 2025, a major glitch appeared within Cloudflare's systems. The root cause was in the Bot Mitigation component. After a routine configuration update, a software bug caused the system to classify most traffic as bots. As the system began blocking massive amounts of traffic, a "chokepoint" was created, failing Threat Management engines due to oversized configuration files.

The Result: The network started returning internal errors (HTTP 500) on many sites. Cloudflareโs team struggled to access their own Dashboard and API to fix settings quickly โ essentially, engineers were locked out of their own system.

Detailed Technical Analysis

  • Root Cause: A configuration change in Bot Mitigation created a massive or conflicting config file, choking the filtering engine.
  • Domino Effect: Due to Cloudflare's interconnected architecture, the failure of a core component caused errors in others like Workers, Access, and WARP.
  • Fixing Difficulty: Engineers had to perform a rollback to previous settings and reconfigure systems step-by-step.

Security Aspect โ Attack or Mistake?

All indicators point to an internal glitch rather than an external attack. This type of failure highlights a crucial point: even systems designed to protect against external attacks can stumble due to internal errors. Clear separation of duties and automated pre-deployment testing are essential.

Practical Recommendations for Organizations

  1. Provider Diversity: Don't rely on a single infrastructure provider; have a backup DNS/CDN ready.
  2. Safe Deployment: Use practices like Canary and Blue-Green deployments.
  3. Circuit Breakers: If an internal component fails, disconnect it temporarily to prevent cascading failures.
  4. Monitoring and Alerting: To identify issues as soon as they emerge.

Quick and Direct Summary

The Cloudflare outage on 11/18/2025 showed how interconnected and centralized the internet has become around major providers. The issue wasn't an external attack, but an internal error in Bot Mitigation that caused global congestion. Solutions include safe deployment, provider diversification, and better engineering contingency plans.

The internet doesn't belong to any single entity โ we must make its design stronger and more resilient to errors.

title.en: The Beginning of Economy and Market Games.. From a Clay Tablet in Babylon to AI Trading in Milliseconds

summary.en: A comprehensive narrative journey of the history of money and trade, from bartering and clay tablets in Babylon to global stock markets, major financial crises, and the AI managing today's markets.

content.en:
The Story of Money and Trade!

This story began a long time ago โ from the days of people bartering stalks of wheat for sheep โ until there were stock exchanges, stocks, bonds, and along the way, transactions made by artificial intelligence (AI) appeared. This post will take you on a narrative journey in the Egyptian dialect, from ancient civilizations to November 6, 2025. We will explain the evolution of the economy, define important terms, and link them to political and social events, all in an engaging and narrative way.

The Start of the Game โ Ancient Civilizations

Once humans settled and began to farm and harvest, a surplus appeared. This surplus was the beginning of trade, which later led to the invention of a stored and transferable value. Thousands of years BC, in lands like Babylon, Egypt, China, and India, trade was a daily habit, but other things appeared with it: partnership contracts, loans, and ownership registration systems. In Babylon, on a clay tablet, they documented partnerships and financing of trade trips, and whoever held the tablet could claim a share of the profits โ in short, these were the first seeds of the idea of profit sharing and ownership that we would later call a stock.

The Emergence of Currency and the Beginning of Trust

When people agreed on one thing with an agreed value, trade became easier: currency. When money remained stable or semi-stable, the role of intermediaries and primitive banks appeared, issuing receipts and documenting ownership and debt, facilitating the transfer of wealth without carrying gold and risking it at sea.

Europe and the Renaissance โ The First Market Tools

In the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, especially in Italy, a system for bills of exchange and methods for transferring wealth between cities appeared. Merchants began using receipts instead of moving real money. The name "Bourse" came from the merchants' meeting places; these were the beginnings of an organized market for trading papers representing ownership or debt bonds.

The Netherlands โ The Mother of Exchanges

What activated the game on a global level was the emergence of the Dutch East India Company (VOC) in 1602. This company issued public shares, and anyone could buy them and have a share of the profits and losses. Here, the first real stock exchange was created in Amsterdam, and shares became representations of ownership in large companies, not just bets on a single trip.

First Speculative Moves โ Short Selling

In Amsterdam, someone started something called short selling: this person borrows shares from someone and sells them, waiting until the price drops to buy them back and return them to the lender, thus pocketing the difference. A simple but dangerous idea, which became the basis for speculative practices to this day.

Bubbles and Learning from Pain โ Tulip and Mississippi

History is full of bubbles: Tulip Mania in the Netherlands is a famous example, and in France, there was John Law's game with the Mississippi Company that created a large bubble and exported false promises of treasures.

Economic Bubble

Simply put, an "economic bubble" happens when the price of something โ like a house, stock, or even a digital currency โ rises much higher than its real value due to obsession and speculation. When the market wakes up and realizes prices are exaggerated, demand suddenly drops, and prices collapse in an instant โ that's when the bubble "bursts."

Short Selling

Short Selling is a smart but very dangerous move used by some investors to profit when prices fall instead of rise. The investor borrows a share they don't own and sells it immediately, expecting its price to drop. When it does, they buy it back at the lower price and return it, keeping the difference.

The Great Depression 1929 โ When the Story Escaped Us

In the 1920s, people were buying a lot of stocks on margin โ paying a small part and borrowing the rest. In October 1929, the market crashed and the bubbles burst: bank failures, high unemployment, and the whole society entered a deep depression. Roosevelt came with the New Deal, imposing regulation on the stock market.

Crisis of 1998 โ The Asian Financial Crisis

This crisis began in 1997 in Southeast Asian countries. These countries had very fast economic growth and borrowed heavily in US dollars. When the dollar rose and global banks withdrew their money, local currencies suddenly lost value.

  • Main Causes: Huge dollar loans without enough guarantees, overconfidence in growth, and weak banking supervision.
  • Results: Collapse of Asian currencies, bankruptcy of large companies, and global market tremors reaching Russia in 1998.

Crisis of 2008 โ The Global Housing Crisis

This crisis was born in the US housing market. Banks were lending to almost anyone (Subprime Mortgages). These loans were bundled into complex securities (MBS and CDOs). When people stopped paying, the system collapsed.

  • Main Causes: Greed in the real estate market, lax lending, and complex financial instruments.
  • Results: Collapse of Lehman Brothers, frozen lending, global recession, and government bailouts.

The 2020 COVID-19 Crisis

In early 2020, the pandemic forced border closures and market shutdowns, disrupting supply chains.

  • Main Causes: Cessation of economic activity due to lockdowns and collapse in demand for tourism and aviation.
  • Results: Global economic contraction, job losses, and massive stimulus packages.

Russia-Ukraine War 2022

The invasion in February 2022 disrupted global energy (oil and gas), wheat, and fertilizer supplies.

  • Results: Rising energy and food prices globally and record inflation in Europe and the US.

AI and Today's Market

AI has flipped the rules: algorithms read news, perform Sentiment Analysis, and execute orders at a pace humans can't reach. While it reduces costs, reliance on it could generate faster collapse patterns if errors occur. As of now, it is not fully effective in the economic sector.

Final Conclusion โ From Babylon's Tablet to Millisecond Algorithms!

This long journey shows us that economics is not just numbers, but the story of humanity itself. From ancient civilizations to AI, the goal remains the same: stability in a volatile sea. Economics is not a game of luck; it is a science, behavior, and the art of managing time and action.

The market has no mercy, but it always teaches, and no one learns for free.

title.en: Our Migrated (Looted) Treasures โ The Tale of Egyptian Antiquities that Went Abroad: Gifts, Deals, Thefts, and Repatriation Efforts

summary.en: A detailed historical analysis of the journey of Egyptian antiquities leaving their land since the French Campaign, through royal gifts and the presidential decree to gift Nubian temples, to modern successes in repatriating smuggled pieces and legal battles for major icons.

content.en:
Quick Introduction - Must Read

Egyptian antiquities are not just stones and statues โ they are a nation's memory, and the story of a civilization speaking for itself. Since Pharaonic times until today, thousands of pieces have left Egypt: some with official approval as an Artifact donation or sale, and some left outside their true right โ through illegal smuggling (Illicit trafficking) or colonialism and excavations that gave finds to foreign missions. This post will walk with you step by step, from the beginning to the present day, sharing all the details, political and economic stories, clear examples of each case, and we will also know what has returned and what is still abroad, how we demand it, and what we can learn to preserve our heritage.

Before Muhammad Ali โ The First Beginnings of Treasures Leaving

Before Muhammad Ali, the French Campaign was the first major door for antiquities leaving. When Napoleon came to Egypt in 1798, he brought scientists, surveyors, and antiquity collectors who gathered pieces and sent them to France as a "scientific discovery." At that time, the concept of archaeological ownership was very blurred, so some pieces like the Rosetta Stone went to England after the British defeated the French, making it a symbol of knowledge and science, but also a symbol of colonial cultural exploitation. These pieces left when there was no law protecting heritage, and the whole world considered Egyptian antiquities an open scientific treasure. With the beginning of the nineteenth century, the idea of Cultural appropriation began to take shape, as colonial countries took heritage and displayed it as evidence of their "civilization."

The Era of Muhammad Ali Pasha โ The Beginning of Archaeological Diplomacy

Muhammad Ali Pasha, the founder of modern Egypt, saw that antiquities could be a powerful political tool. In his time, international relations were based on large symbolic gifts. So he began giving antiquities as Diplomatic gifts to the kings of Europe. The most famous of them is the famous Cleopatra's Needle, which he gifted to Queen Victoria in 1819 โ which was moved to London and erected there in 1878, and another obelisk went to New York in 1877 as a gift from Khedive Ismail after the opening of the Suez Canal. These two obelisks stand today in London and New York as global symbols, but their origin is purely Egyptian. Khedive Ismail also gifted France the Luxor Temple obelisk in 1833, which was erected in Place de la Concorde in Paris. This was one of the most prominent moments of Egyptian cultural diplomacy, but it was also the beginning of a series of archaeological symbols leaving their land.

The Era of Ismail and Farouk โ Cultural and Political Exchange

In the time of Ismail, Egypt was living through a period of openness to Europe, and he was trying to present a "modern" image of the country. So it was natural for him to use antiquities as a political tool, especially after the Suez Canal project. In contrast, some foreigners took their chances and entered archaeological excavations under agreements that allowed them to take "half of the finds." In the era of King Farouk, the situation changed a bit. Egypt became more aware of the value of its antiquities, but some pieces were still leaving through auctions and personal gifts. At that time, the idea that "heritage is not the property of the ruler, but the property of the people" began to be established.

The Nubian Temples and the High Dam โ The Turning Point

When Egypt decided to build the High Dam in the sixties, a disaster appeared: Lake Nasser waters would completely submerge the Nubian monuments. UNESCO launched the Nubian Monuments Rescue Campaign, in which more than 50 countries participated. What happened was a human and scientific epic: temples like Abu Simbel and Philae were dismantled stone by stone and moved, and it was a great engineering achievement. But in exchange for the help, Egypt decided to thank some of the countries that participated by gifting small temples from Nubia โ and this was done by an official decree from President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

The Gifted Temples โ Gratitude or Loss?

In 1966, Presidential Decree No. 4647 was issued, which stipulated the gifting of five complete temples as a token of thanks and affection to the countries participating in saving the Nubian monuments. The details are as follows:

  • Temple of Dendur: Gifted to the United States of America, and moved to the Metropolitan Museum in New York. The temple is Roman from the era of Emperor Augustus, and has now become one of the most famous landmarks inside the museum.
  • Temple of Debod: Went to Spain, and moved to the Debod Garden in Madrid in 1968, becoming a well-known tourist attraction.
  • Temple of Taffa: Gifted to the Netherlands, and is currently located in the Rijksmuseum in Leiden.
  • Temple of Ellesiya: Went to Italy, and is displayed in the Turin Museum.
  • Kalabsha Gate: Gifted to Germany, and is currently displayed in the Berlin Museum.

The issue at the time was controversial. Some saw these as "diplomatic thank-you gifts," not a loss, and others said: "How can we gift entire temples from our heritage?". The truth is that those who restored and saved the Abu Simbel temple were a coalition of Swedish, French, and Egyptian companies in cooperation with UNESCO, and not all countries that participated received a gift. Thus, Gamal Abdel Nasser handed over Egypt missing Sudan, Sinai, and some temples like the Temple of Dendur, the Roman temple, Temple of Taffa, Temple of Debod, Temple of Ellesiya, and the Kalabsha Gate.

Between Gift and Politics โ Why Did This Happen?

This decision had a clear political background: Egypt was facing an economic blockade after the Tripartite Aggression (1956), and needed international and moral support. The idea of gifting was part of Cultural diplomacy โ meaning building a bridge of cooperation through heritage. But the result is that these antiquities today have become part of world museums that attract millions of visitors annually, and are treated as if they are "global," despite being purely Egyptian in origin.

Antiquities that Left through Exploration and Smuggling

From the 19th and 20th centuries, thousands of pieces left in a "legal" way at the time, but they are now considered Colonial exploitation. European missions were digging and taking part of the finds, and that was the official system. But after the British occupation, there was a very large tolerance for pieces leaving. At the same time, very massive smuggling operations took place โ small pieces, statues, coffins, and even mummies. Some pieces were smuggled in tea boxes, musical instruments, or modern sculptures.

Repatriation of Egyptian Antiquities โ Return After a Long Absence

From the beginning of the twenty-first century, especially after 2011, Egypt entered a real battle against antiquity smuggling gangs that were very active during the chaos, and began a wide repatriation campaign for every piece that left the country illegally. The matter was not simple, but it became an Egyptian international success story being written line by line.

  • In 2018: A very big event happened when Italian authorities discovered inside a diplomatic container coming from the port of Alexandria boxes containing thousands of small Egyptian artifacts, including Pharaonic amulets, pottery vessels, and ancient coins in massive numbers reaching more than 21,000 pieces! The Italian authorities seized them immediately, and contact was made between the Italian prosecution and the Egyptian embassy there. After months of investigations, Egypt proved with evidence that this container belonged to an international smuggling network, and Italy immediately issued an official decree to return all pieces to Egypt. In an official celebration in Cairo, the Minister of Antiquities received these pieces himself, and part of them was later displayed in a special exhibition in the Egyptian Museum under the title "Returnees to the Homeland."
  • In 2019: The whole world talked about one of the most important antiquity cases in modern history: The Golden Coffin of the priest Nedjemankh. The coffin was completely covered in pure gold and decorated with precise inscriptions from the Ptolemaic era. After it was stolen from Minya Governorate in 2011 during the period of security vacuum, it was sold by an international smuggling network with forged papers. The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York bought it in 2017 for $4 million based on fake documents saying it left Egypt legally in 1971. But after extensive investigations by Egyptian authorities in cooperation with the New York District Attorney's Office, it turned out that all the papers were forged (Forged provenance documents) and that the coffin left by smuggling. In February 2019, America issued an official decree to return the coffin, and in a big celebration in Cairo, the Egyptian government received it, and the American museum officially apologized and said that Egypt is its only legitimate owner. Today the coffin is displayed in the National Museum of Egyptian Civilization in Fustat in a special hall, and it is considered a symbol of restoring Egyptian archaeological dignity.
  • Year 2021: Was also full of activity, when the Egyptian antiquity team managed to track a rare statue head of King Thutmose III that was smuggled secretly through Europe and reached the Netherlands. After negotiations that lasted months between the Egyptian ministries of Foreign Affairs and Justice and their Dutch counterparts, an official agreement was signed to return the head. In November 2025, during an official visit by the Dutch Prime Minister to attend the opening of the Grand Egyptian Museum, he himself announced the official handover of the head to Egypt amidst global media coverage, and the moment was described as "restoring consideration to the civilizational identity."
  • In 2022: A new case appeared in the United States when the Metropolitan Museum itself returned 16 rare artifacts after the Public Prosecution in New York proved they were smuggled. These pieces consisted of small statues, parts of wooden coffins, and limestone statues from different eras, some from the Saqqara and Luxor tombs. Investigations proved that one smuggling network was behind the exit of most of them, and the prosecution's decision obligated the American museum to deliver them immediately to the Egyptian government. Indeed, the pieces returned to Cairo and were received by the Grand Egyptian Museum within a special wing for recovered pieces.
  • As for the year 2023: It witnessed one of the stories cited as an example of international cooperation. Italian authorities discovered four very rare pieces in one of the private exhibitions, including part of a wooden coffin colored with amazing drawings and precise hieroglyphic inscriptions, a sandstone column with a Pharaonic cartouche, small funerary pottery vessels, and part of ancient temple inscriptions. The Italian authorities, after reviewing the documents, confirmed their source was Egypt, so contact was made immediately with the Egyptian embassy, and in an official ceremony in Rome, the Italian Ministry of Culture handed the four pieces to Egypt. The pieces arrived on a military plane to Cairo in July 2023, and were transferred directly to restoration stores in the National Museum of Civilization.
  • In the same year: New Zealand announced the return of human mummy remains that were in one of its local museums since the nineteenth century, and were displayed as an "Anthropological Specimen" without Egypt's permission. After negotiations that lasted more than two years between the Egyptian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the New Zealand government, the remains returned completely in a special box decorated with the flag of Egypt, and were properly buried in the mummy tombs at the National Museum of Civilization, amidst symbolic ceremonies attended by representatives from UNESCO.
  • Also in the United States: The piece known as the "Green Coffin" returned in 2023, which is a massive dark green wooden coffin with precise Pharaonic inscriptions, stolen from Egypt and moved through a smuggling network to several countries until it reached America. The Houston Museum of Fine Arts bought it from a private auction, but after forged documents and an official report from Egypt appeared, an investigation was opened, and American authorities ruled that the coffin was stolen and returned to Egypt officially.

Egypt has also managed to recover during the last five years more than 30,000 artifacts from different countries such as France, England, America, Germany, UAE, Saudi Arabia, and Austria. Some were offered for sale in international auctions like Christieโs and Sothebyโs, and Egyptian authorities continuously monitor any announcement of pieces suspected to be Egyptian. What is happening now is that Egypt has a specialized unit within the Ministry of Antiquities called the "Stolen Antiquities Recovery Unit," which handles following up on these cases legally and diplomatically, and uses the latest Digital Provenance Tracking techniques to track the history of each piece archaeologically and prove its origin. The result is that Egypt has become one of the most successful countries in the world in returning its stolen antiquities, and not only that, but it has also become a role model in international cooperation in the field of protecting human heritage. Every piece that returns is not just a stone or a statue, it is a story of a homeland to which part of its stolen history returns.

Pieces Still Outside โ The Tale of Treasures that Haven't Returned

Despite all that Egypt has managed to return of its looted antiquities during the past years, there are still very massive treasures outside the country, pieces considered among the greatest produced by ancient Egyptian civilization, and they are still subject to the issue of "Cultural Ownership" between Egypt and foreign museums.

  • The first and most famous example: is the Rosetta Stone, which was discovered in 1799 by a French officer from Napoleon's army in the city of Rashid, and because of which scientists were able to decipher the symbols of the hieroglyphic language. The stone was confiscated from the French after their defeat in the 1801 campaign, and moved to Britain under the Alexandria Agreement which handed over most of the French finds at that time to the British government, and since then it has been displayed in the British Museum in London. Egypt has officially demanded the return of the stone more than 5 times, especially after the international campaign led by Dr. Zahi Hawass which collected signatures from archaeologists from all over the world, but the British Museum refuses on the pretext that the stone has become part of the "World Heritage of Humanity" and that it must remain available to the whole world. But Egypt has not stopped demanding, and the legal cases and negotiations are still open until today.
  • The second piece: making a global stir is the Nefertiti Bust, one of the most beautiful and complete statues that came out of ancient Egypt. The statue was discovered in 1912 by German archaeologist Ludwig Borchardt in the Tell el-Amarna area, and at that time there was a "Division System" that gave foreign missions the right to half of the finds, but Borchardt hid the truth of the statue from the Egyptian committee and said it was "just a broken statue," so he could smuggle it to Germany. The statue was then moved to the Berlin Museum in 1924, and displayed there in a special hall dedicated to Queen Nefertiti. Since then, Egypt has officially demanded the return of the statue dozens of times, and each time it is met with a flat German refusal on the pretext that it left "legally at the time." However, all modern documents confirm that the method of its exit involved fraud and manipulation, and that the statue was indeed taken dishonestly.
  • The third piece: which is considered one of the most amazing things that came out of Egyptian temples, is the Zodiac of Dendera, a massive stone slab depicting stars, constellations, and the ancient Egyptian calendar with amazing precision. The slab was fixed in the ceiling of the Dendera Temple in Qena, but in 1820 a group of Frenchmen led by engineer Sebastian Saulnier cut it from the ceiling and moved it to France with the help of the French consul, and it has been displayed in the Louvre Museum in Paris ever since. Egypt has demanded its return more than once, especially after 2009 when the Grand Egyptian Museum began collecting precise digital copies of these pieces in preparation for officially demanding them, but France said it left before the existence of laws prohibiting the export of antiquities, and therefore it is not legally obligated to return it.

But the matter does not stop at these three, there are dozens of other pieces that Egypt is currently chasing in international courts and negotiations, such as:

  • The seated statue of Ramses II located in Turin, Italy.
  • The Seated Scribe statue in the Louvre Museum, which has a huge controversy about its true source.
  • The head of Queen Hatshepsut's statue (Hatshepsut Bust) in the Metropolitan Museum in New York.
  • Parts of the Saqqara and Luxor tomb walls that were cut and moved in the 19th century to European museums.

All these pieces Egypt is still seeking to return officially, whether through diplomatic negotiations or via international laws for heritage protection. While foreign museums claim these pieces "belong to all of humanity," Egypt always responds with one simple but powerful sentence:

"Human heritage must be displayed to the world, but in its original home."

This is the heart of the cultural conflict still ongoing today, between those who see these antiquities as world heritage, and Egypt which sees them as part of its soul and identity that must return to its mother home.

The Impact of Antiquities Leaving on Egyptians

These antiquities are not just stones. Their exit has had a significant social and cultural impact:

  • Loss of a sense of historical ownership.
  • Weakening of tourism, because part of the original treasures became outside the country.
  • Division in opinion between those who see that their presence outside introduces the world to Egypt, and those who see it as an unforgivable civilizational theft.

Who has the Right to Dispose of History?

The truth is that no one has the right to dispose of a whole country's heritage, not a president, a king, or a government. This heritage belongs to the nation, to all Egyptians, not to a specific time era. This is what the whole world has recently begun to recognize under the umbrella of World Heritage Conventions.

The Road Ahead

To return what is gone and preserve the rest:

  1. Stronger laws to protect antiquities are necessary.
  2. True public awareness of the value of heritage.
  3. Fair international cooperation based on mutual respect.
  4. Facing Illicit trafficking by all legal and technical means.
  5. Displaying antiquities abroad temporarily, not permanently โ a Cultural loan instead of a sale or gift.

Conclusion

Since the time of the Pharaohs, Egyptian antiquities have been traveling, but the difference is that in the past it was out of ignorance or greed, and now out of awareness and diplomacy. Political gifts like the Nubian temples were part of a difficult stage in our history, but smuggling and theft were and still are a crime against the Egyptian memory. Today, Egypt is returning what was taken, preserving the rest, and the whole world has started to hear its voice. Heritage is not just history... it is identity. And whoever squanders their identity loses their future before their past.

title.en: Politics as the Art of Interests: Why We Shouldn't Give Absolute Support to Individuals?

summary.en: An analysis of political philosophy based on shifting interests rather than fixed principles, featuring quotes from global and Arab thinkers on the nature of the political game and the need for public awareness.

content.en:
I always say: Don't give absolute support to individuals, groups, or parties; instead, support positions, trends, ideas, or principles.

Because basically, no politician remains constant in all their ideas, trends, positions, or principles. That is the game of politics; it is primarily governed by the current situation and interests, that's it.

Politics is not always what it seems... and it was never about permanent love or hate! The real catastrophe isn't the politicians themselves... no, it's the people who don't understand politics and take every word said seriously!

Historical Quotes on Politics:

  • George Orwell: "Political language is designed to make lies sound truthful and murder respectable."
  • Niccolรฒ Machiavelli: "It is better to be feared than loved, if you cannot be both."
  • Voltaire: "Politics is the art of lying on purpose."
  • Mark Twain: "Politicians are people who, when they see the light at the end of the tunnel, go there and turn it off."
  • Jamal al-Din al-Afghani: "Politics for us is the art of lying, hypocrisy, and keeping up with the powerful."
  • Mustafa Mahmoud: "Politics in our countries is the art of using slogans to cover up failure."

So, don't get attached to any politician, and don't be fanatical about any political enmity... because in most cases, this enmity isn't permanent. On the contrary, it might later turn into a strategic friendship that serves both parties' interests, and then you'll be the only one who took things more seriously than the owners themselves!

Conclusion:

Politics is a game... and whoever doesn't understand its rules watches while thinking they are participating!

title.en: A Journey into Ancient Egyptian Religion Between Prophets and Gods: Was Ancient Egyptian Religion More Monotheistic Than We Think? Thoth and Idris... Between Religion and History

summary.en: A comprehensive study linking prophetic figures (Prophet Idris) with Ancient Egyptian beliefs (Thoth), featuring historical and scientific analysis of pyramids, writing, and governance philosophy, while clarifying the linguistic and historical truth of the title 'Pharaoh' and its relation to Ramses II.

content.en:
Before we begin with the main topic, you must check this introductory post first to avoid any misunderstandings ๐

[https://www.facebook.com/share/p/1BvMuU3rea/]

Note: This is a very long post ๐

Introduction

Let's tell a long story about a people who built an unprecedented civilization. This post takes you on a journey from prehistoric times to when the pyramids became a mark in human history. The essence of Egyptian belief was formed over millennia, embodied in the concept of Maatโcosmic order and justice.

Thoth and Idris โ Are They the Same?

In Islamic and traditional narratives, there is a link between Prophet Idris (Enoch) and the Egyptian deity Thoth. Thoth is the god of wisdom, writing, and the moonโthe one credited with inventing writing. In Islamic tradition, Idris was among the first to learn writing and science. The functional description of Thoth (teaching arithmetic, writing, and astronomy) closely resembles the image of Idris. While not definitive historical proof, the similarity of roles is compelling to many.

From Pre-Dynastic to the Old Kingdom

As people moved from hunting to agriculture, a class of leaders and priests emerged, developing deities linked to nature: the Nile, the Sun, and the Earth. By 3100 BCE, a organized pantheon of gods appeared with distinct symbols and rituals. Over time, state deities like Amun rose, and the Pharaoh represented the living embodiment of Maat.

Akhenaten's Monotheistic Experiment

Akhenaten attempted a religious revolution by centralizing the worship of the Aten (the sun disk). This experiment was clear in art and statecraft, building a new city dedicated to Aten. It is described as 'monolatry' rather than modern monotheism, but it proves the existence of monotheistic currents within Egyptian religion.

The Pyramids: A Scientific Blackboard?

Pyramids are more than tombs; they are hundreds of thousands of engineering hours. Their precise alignment and weight distribution show an advanced understanding of physics. Some accounts suggest these buildings were intended to preserve sciences from a Great Flood. Modern studies continue to marvel at the techniques used for hauling and lifting massive stones.

Astronomy and Writing

Hieroglyphics evolved from ritual symbols to administrative records. Papyri like Rhind and Ebers showcase mathematical and medical knowledge. Astronomy was vital for predicting floods and dividing the year, directly influencing the construction of temples and pyramids.

The Mystery of 'Pharaoh': Name or Title?

The Quran clarifies that "Pharaoh" was a proper name of a person, not a general title for all kings. Linguistic evidence:

  • Grouped with personal names: "Korah, Pharaoh, and Haman."
  • Addressed directly: "O Pharaoh," without the definite article used for titles like "The King."
  • In Egyptian history, there is no official title named "Pharaoh" for the king in early records; titles like 'Nesut-Bity' were used instead.

The Myth: Is Moses' Pharaoh Ramses II?

Historical and Quranic evidence suggests otherwise:

  • Ramses II died in his 90s with severe health issues, making a chariot chase unlikely.
  • The Quran says Pharaoh's works were destroyed, yet Ramses' monuments stand everywhere (Luxor, Abu Simbel).
  • Moses' Pharaoh was childless according to the text, while Ramses had over 100 children.
  • No Egyptian records mention the exodus or the divine plagues during Ramses' reign.

Scientific Details: Math, Engineering, and Medicine

The Rhind Papyrus includes division and calculations of areas and volumes used for land surveying and labor rations. In construction, the use of inclined planes and load-bearing calculations was advanced. The Ebers Papyrus is a medical encyclopedia containing herbal recipes and simple surgical methods. They understood basic sterilization and dental work.

Religion and Economy

Temples were not just places of worship but massive economic centers. Priests owned land, managed grain stores, and paid wages. Religious life was intertwined with the economy through offerings and the massive labor movement required for monument maintenance.

Conclusion

Ancient Egyptian civilization was not just statues; it was a civilization of mind, heart, and faith. Pharaoh was not a title, and the civilization was not inherently 'kafir' as some think; it was the first to unify God and sanctify light, order, and truth. Egypt was and remains the land of prophets and sages, not just tyrants. We should celebrate this scientific and cultural legacy.

title.en: Secrets of Stone and Papyrus โ Names of Egypt Throughout History, and Why Ancient Egyptian Science Still Baffles Scientists, Making Every Number a Story?

summary.en: A comprehensive and deep analysis of Egypt's historical identity through its various names and scientific achievements in engineering, astronomy, medicine, and chemistry, focusing on numerical data and archaeological facts related to the pyramids, mummification, and the Grand Egyptian Museum.

content.en:
Before we begin with the main topic, you must check this post first to avoid any misunderstandings ๐

[https://www.facebook.com/share/p/1BvMuU3rea/]

Note: This is a very long post

Introduction

Imagine traveling back thousands of years to a time when the sands whispered secrets yet understood today. The Ancient Egyptians built with stone and mind, creating wonders we now try to comprehend with supercomputers and complex physics. These people were true scientists before the word "Science" was even uttered. From tracking stars to preserving bodies for millennia, Ancient Egypt is an open laboratory of the human mind, featuring engineering that defies gravity and medicine using complex chemistry.

Names of Egypt Throughout History

  • Kemet: The Black Land
    The first known name, referring to the fertile black silt left after the Nile flood. For them, black was a symbol of life and rebirth.
  • Deshret: The Red Land
    Referring to the harsh deserts surrounding the Nile Valley, representing danger and the unknown.
  • Ta-Mery: The Beloved Land
    Literally meaning the cultivated land or the land of love, expressing the deep bond with the Nile.
  • Tawy: The Two Lands
    Referring to Upper and Lower Egypt, unified under one crown.
  • Idbwy: The Two Banks
    Symbolizing the balance between the East (sunrise/life) and the West (sunset/journey of the soul).
  • Aigyptos: The Greek name mentioned in Homer's Odyssey, likely derived from "Hwt-Ka-Ptah" (House of the Soul of Ptah). This evolved into the modern name "Egypt."

Mizraim: The Ancient Origins

In religious traditions, Mizraim is a grandson of Noah (son of Ham). After the flood, he settled around the Nile. This lineage is recorded in the Book of Genesis and later Islamic traditions. Descendants include the Pathrusim (linked to Pathros/Upper Egypt), Casluhim, and Naphtuhim. While archaeological science seeks physical evidence, these religious narratives provide a cultural foundation for the nation's origins.

Early Beginnings and the Nile

Civilization began to take shape around 5000โ4000 BCE, with unification around 3100 BCE. They developed a 365-day calendar linked to the star Sirius to predict floods and divided the night into 36 Decans for timekeeping.

Engineering and the Pyramids by Numbers

The Great Pyramid of Khufu:

  • Construction: Approx. 2580โ2560 BCE.
  • Height: Originally 146.6m (now 138.8m).
  • Base Area: ~53,000 square meters.
  • Stone Count: ~2.3โ2.6 million blocks.
  • Weight: Average 2.5 tons per block; granite slabs in the King's chamber reach 70 tons.
  • Precision: Aligned to True North with less than 0.05ยฐ deviation.

Labor and Logistics: Recent discoveries suggest a highly organized workforce rather than slaves. Estimates range from 10,000 to 30,000 regular workers, peaking at 100,000 seasonally.

Mummification and Medicine

The 70-day mummification process involved removing organs and dehydrating the body with natron for 40 days. Medical papyri like Edwin Smith (48 surgical cases) and Ebers (800 recipes) show sophisticated anatomical and chemical knowledge, using plant oils and resins.

Chemistry and Nanomaterials: Egyptian Blue

Egyptian Blue (CaCuSiโOโโ) was synthesized at 800โ1000ยฐC. Modern labs study its infrared (IR) emission properties, often comparing its crystalline structure to modern nanomaterials.

The Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM)

Spanning 500,000 sqm, it houses over 100,000 artifacts, including the full Tutankhamun collection. It features the region's largest restoration center using non-destructive analysis technologies.

Conclusion

From Kemet to Egypt, this is a journey of thousands of years of science and survival. The Ancient Egyptians built with knowledge before stone. Today, it is our duty to follow their footsteps in innovation and progress.

title.en: Between Pharaohs (Ancient Egyptians) and Arabs.. The Truth No One Wants to Hear!

summary.en: An explanatory article addressing the debate over Egyptian identity, balancing pride in Ancient Egyptian civilization as a great human achievement with respect for Arabic and Islamic identity, while warning against racial fanaticism or pagan sanctification.

content.en:
This post is for clarification only so that future posts are not misunderstood ๐

Ancient Egyptian Civilization.. Timeless Genius

To be clear, the Ancient Egyptian civilization was one of the greatest and most intelligent civilizations known to human history. Egyptians in the past achieved legendary engineering and intellectual feats that the whole world is still marveled by! If anyone tries to diminish its value or deny its merit, they are either ignorant or biased.

However, we must also remember that blind hatred for Arabs (by the 'Kemites' and their followers) is unacceptable, because the Prophet ๏ทบ himself was Arab, and that alone is a great honor.

A Hadith Revealing the True Meaning

The Prophet ๏ทบ said to Salman the Persian (may Allah be pleased with him):

"O Salman, do not hate me, lest you leave your religion." He asked: "O Messenger of Allah, how could I hate you when through you Allah guided us?" He replied: "By hating the Arabs, you hate me."

This means that those who hate Arabs out of pure tribalism or fanaticism are as if they hate the Prophet ๏ทบ himself. We should not let negative stances from some individuals be a reason to hate an entire nation.

Love for Ancient Civilizations.. Between Halal and Haram

  1. First: Cultural & Historical Love: Such as literature, poetry, architecture, traditions, and ancient ethics. This is not forbidden as long as it does not involve arrogance or pre-Islamic (Jahili) pride over others. Muslims have always loved and taught the poetry of the Jahiliyyah period, despite slight transgressions, because the goal was cultural, not religious.
  2. Second: Religious Pagan Love: This is when the love is directed towards idols that were once worshipped or myths that sanctify disbelief (as the 'Kemites' do ๐). This is strictly forbidden because it affects Monotheism (Tawhid) and falls under Shirk (associating partners with Allah).
  3. Third: Mixed Context: Items containing both a civilizational and religious aspect. This is governed by context: Is the admiration scientific and cultural? Or religious sanctification? It is always better to avoid anything doubtful.

Egyptians and the Pharaonic Civilization

Most Egyptians' love for their ancient civilization falls under the first typeโnatural cultural and civilizational pride. This is not wrong or blameworthy as long as there is no sanctification, worship, or arrogance. However, there is another group, whom we call 'Kemites,' whose love is more religious than civilizational; this is dangerous and rejected. Transitioning from pride to worship is a red line in Islam.

Moderate Islamists of the Past

In the first half of the 20th century, there were moderate Muslim thinkers like Mustafa Sadiq al-Rafi'i, who managed to combine his faith in his religion with pride in his Egyptian identity. He did not hate the ancient civilization nor did he worship it; rather, he respected it as a civilizational symbol, much like his respect for Jahiliyyah poetry. Al-Rafi'i said in his famous poetry:

"I am an Egyptian built by those who built, the pyramid of time that defied annihilation..."

This shows he was proud of his civilization and history without deviating from his religion or falling into false sanctification. If Rafi'i wrote this today, many would mock him; some would call him a 'Kemite' and others would say 'he has gone mad'!

Conclusion

Your love for your civilization is not forbidden nor against your religion, as long as it is the love of pride and belonging, not worship or sanctification. Just as blind hatred for Arabs is wrong, blind sanctification of Pharaohs is also wrong. Be balanced.. be proud of your mind, your history, and your religion at the same time. And in the end? Whoever dislikes this talk from either side... can go jump off a cliff ๐

title.en: The Grand Egyptian Museum โ When Egypt Awakens to Reveal the Secrets of Civilization: Official Opening and Full Details

summary.en: Comprehensive coverage of the Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM) opening on November 1, 2025, detailing the project's history, unique architectural design, King Tutankhamun's treasures, and the scientific and technical advancements in restoration labs, highlighting its global status as the world's largest museum dedicated to a single civilization.

content.en:
A Brief Introduction Before the Journey

On Saturday, November 1, 2025, the Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM) officially opened. This is not just a regular event; it is a new chapter in the story of Egyptian civilization. This museum is not just a building adorned with artifacts; it is a historical, scientific, and tourist experience that gathers thousands of years in one place.

The Beginning: Dream, Persistence, and Steadfastness

The idea for the museum project dates back decadesโa dream to have all of Egypt's heritage in one place to secure, protect, and display it in the best possible way. The idea began in 2002 when Egypt launched an international architectural competition won by the Irish firm Heneghan Peng Architects. The foundation stone was laid in 2002 near the Giza Pyramids, and actual construction began in 2005.

Despite challenges like the 2011 political events and the COVID-19 pandemic, the Egyptian state maintained it as a national project. After more than 20 years of planning, construction, and restoration, it officially opened on November 1, 2025, as the largest archaeological museum in the world.

Location and Design: Museum and Pyramid.. A Visual Harmony

The museum is built on the Giza plateau about 2 kilometers from the pyramids, creating a visual dialogue between modern architectural masterpiece and ancient monuments. The total area is approximately 500,000 square meters (about 70 football fields), making it the largest museum in the world dedicated to a single civilization.

The Grand Egyptian Museum.. A Story of a Nation

The GEM is one of the rarest museums because it tells the story of an entire civilization from its original land, not from stolen items or auctions. Every artifact inside is purely Egyptian, discovered on Egyptian soil.

Why is it called the Fourth Pyramid?

  • Largest museum dedicated to one civilization: Every hall tells a chapter of history chronologically and interactively.
  • Museum with zero stolen pieces: Everything was discovered within Egyptian borders.
  • Over 100,000 artifacts: A massive number surpassing major global museums.
  • A 17+ year construction journey: Spanning half a million square meters.
  • 12 main exhibition halls: Including the massive Tutankhamun hall (7,500 sqm) housing over 5,000 items shown together for the first time.
  • Largest restoration center in the MEA: Equipped with the latest preservation and environmental treatment technology.

Tutankhamun: The Golden Heart

The Tutankhamun wing is the center of the event. For the first time, all 5,000+ items from his tomb discovered in 1922 are displayed together. The Egyptian restoration team used scientific precision to preserve these treasures while respecting their sanctity.

Scientific Lab and Restoration Center

The museum houses the largest restoration center in the Middle East and Africa. Labs use technologies like 3D scanning, infrared analysis, and X-ray fluorescence. A key research area is 'Egyptian Blue' (Calcium Copper Silicate - CaCuSiโOโโ), an ancient pigment whose nanomaterial properties are now being studied by modern scientists.

The Ancient Egyptian: A Genius Before Science Was Named

  • First synthetic pigment: Egyptian Blue, the first nanomaterial in human history.
  • Hieroglyphics: A complex phonetic and semantic language.
  • Engineering Precision: Calculating pyramid angles relative to Earth's curvature.
  • Medicine and Mummification: A stunning blend of Anatomy, Chemistry, and Medicine.

Technology in Exhibition

The GEM bridges the old and new through mixed reality (MR), interactive screens, and a specific UX/UI design to facilitate the visitor's journey from the Grand Stairs to the colossal statue of Ramses.

Global Presence: Egypt's Message to the World

The opening saw 79 official delegations, including 39 led by kings, princes, and heads of state from countries like Saudi Arabia, Germany, France, and the USA, proving Egypt's role as a guardian of global civilization.

Conclusion

The Grand Egyptian Museum is not just a building; it is a new birth certificate for a civilization thousands of years old. Standing near the pyramids, it acts as a Fourth Pyramidโa witness to the past and a door to the future.

title.en: A Vanishing Identity: The Uyghurs Between History and Surveillance, a Tale of Suppression and Resistance

summary.en: A comprehensive and detailed analysis of the Uyghur issue in Xinjiang, exploring their historical roots, Chinese government policies, re-education camps, technological surveillance, and violations targeting language, education, and the rights of women and children.

content.en:
An Identity Vanishing in Silence: The Uyghur Story

This story is not just a passing news headlineโit is the life of an entire people whose language and heritage are at actual risk. We will discuss history, politics, oppression, and why the Chinese state has taken this path.

Origin and Cultural Roots

The Uyghurs are a Turkic people, indigenous to the Tarim Basin and vast areas of the Xinjiang region. Their presence there is a historical cultural space on the Silk Road. Islam entered centuries ago and merged with local traditions. The Uyghur language is historically written in Arabic script and contains a poetic and musical treasure passed down through generations.

Government Strategy and "Modernization" Policies

From Beijing's perspective, Xinjiang is a highly strategic region; it has oil, gas, and cotton resources and is part of the "Belt and Road" project. The state encouraged mass migration of the Han ethnicity and prioritized Mandarin in education and administration, creating a rift between material development and the indigenous people's sense of marginalization.

Camps and Mass Surveillance

  • Camps: Facilities appeared that the government called "Vocational Training Centers," but international reports confirmed they are detention centers for forced ideological education.
  • Technology: Xinjiang has turned into a laboratory for surveillance using Face Recognition systems, biometric databases, and Artificial Intelligence (AI).

Cultural and Social Violations

  • Language Erasure: Generalizing education in Mandarin and reducing the role of the mother tongue.
  • Forced Labor: Reports revealed cases of forced labor, especially in the textile and cotton sectors.
  • Reproductive Rights: Documentation of forced sterilization and a significant drop in birth rates.
  • Separation of Children: Moving children to boarding schools away from their families to reshape them culturally.

Why the Uyghurs Specifically?

Unlike other Muslims in China such as the "Hui," the Uyghurs have a distinct language, cultural ties to Central Asia, and a sensitive geographical location, leading Beijing to treat them as a threat to national security and separatism.

Practical Steps to Contribute:

  1. Read and educate others about the issue from reliable sources.
  2. Avoid buying products suspected of being linked to forced labor.
  3. Support human rights organizations documenting these violations.
  4. Demand diplomatic actions and independent investigations.

Summary

The Uyghurs are facing a systematic campaign targeting their identity itself. The world faces two choices: effective pressure to curb violations or silence that leads to the total erosion of this identity.
